7,052 “Hits” in February!

Wednesday, February 28th, 2007

The statistical counter on my website indicates that the site has had 7,052 “hits” for the month of February.

If those “hits” could be transformed to “signatures” for a “Recall Schlange” campaign, the hard work of signature collection would be half way completed to qualify the item for the ballot!

Just a thought.

Executive Office Communication Silent

Wednesday, February 28th, 2007

It has been three weeks since MSJC Board Members, Kadow, Sparkman, Schlange released President Mark Zacovic without cause and without comment.

Since that time, no information or substantial communication regarding the district has been provided to me as a trustee. To date, my inquiry e-mail for a legal opinion regarding Kadow’s appointment of J. Tyler as “Acting S/P”, without board discussion and/or no formal board action, has not been provided. I was provided a brief response stating that legal counsel would be available at the March meeting to answer questions or concerns.

It would seem that after three full weeks, the executive office or Board Chair would at the very least provide board members with an overview and/or update since the dismissal action of February 8th.

In the interest of regular communication, Dr. Zacovic provided board members with a regular biweekly memorandum highlighting current district issues and happenings. This regular update was very much appreciated. Under the “Giese” administration, to my knowledge, there was never regular information provided, or at least not provided to me.

Present communication style from the “Kadow/Tyler” executive office mirrors my past experience with the “Giese” administration. Is the “Wizard” behind the curtain?

“Zacovic made students his top priority” by Sarah Malizia

Tuesday, February 27th, 2007

Today, in the North County Times a letter to the editor appeared written by Sarah Malizia. The letter addressed comments of Mr. Roger Ziemer, who wrote a letter to the editor on February 18, 2007 in support of Joan Sparkman for her commitment to education, and also as the known “Matriarch of Southwest Riverside County”. Due to Sparkman’s status, Mr. Ziemer inferred that her decision to dismiss Mark Zacovic should not be questioned. Why? Because she is Joan Sparkman.

Ms Malizia’s letter stated in part “This whole problem has nothing to do with Sparkman’s award. It is about an individual using a position on a board in the wrong way –exerting one’s power at the expense of another’s career, institution and community because things were not supported as these people of position wanted budgetary funds to be!”

Blog: Sparkman’s decision needs to be examined and questioned by every thinking person within her community. Any public official should be able to explain their vote. The “no cause” answer is disingenuous. How do three individuals agree on “no cause”? And if three know why they agreed, why not inform the other two?

It did not surprise me to read the letter last week from Roger Ziemer in support of Sparkman. Ziemer sits as a Director on the Southwest California Legislative Counsel (SCLC) with Sparkman who is the Chair. Mr. Dennis Franke, an employee or representative of AG Kading Group LLC, developer of the Temecula Education Center, also sits as a Director on the SCLC board with Sparkman.

One can only speculate as to why Sparkman was so involved with the negotiation of the MSJC lease and on more than one occasion gave the strong public appearance of being involved with other potential lessees for the project. Was she hired by Kading for public relations on the project? Why use Sparkman? Developers normally have in-house personnel to negotiate leases? Could Sparkman have some type of conflict or personal interest in that project beyond MSJC?

Sparkman’s not talking, so one can only speculate. However, her high profile involvement in this project seems above and beyond normal “trustee” business.

Dr. Mark Zacovic’s Performance “Outstanding” On FTES Growth at P1

Monday, February 26th, 2007

First Principal Apportionment Report (P1) posted on the Chancellors Office Website shows FTES at MSJC up +784, (9%)!

The report shows at P1, for the 06/07 year, the college has earned $3,350,579 of the $3,942,958 in state available growth apportionment funding.

Under Dr. Zacovic’s leadership FTES growth performance at MSJC is nearly 8 times that of last years performance under Dick Giese, Interim S/P.

Under the Giese administration, the recalculation final report for the 05/06 year shows that MSJC grew +153 FTES, (1.8%) earning $613,145 and leaving the balance of nearly $2,900,000 at the state table unearned in a fully funded year.

There is no comparison in FTES growth performance between Mark Zacovic and that of the Giese administration. Under the Giese administration the college failed to make “Cap” four of six years leaving accumulatively over 5 million dollars in available student growth allocation at the state table.

With the new leadership of Dr. Zacovic , MSJC appears to be well on its way to making “Cap” for the 06/07 year, a very good thing for the students we serve.

Kudos to Dr. Zacovic, VP of Instruction, Pamela Deegan, and all faculty/staff for these outstanding results. You are to all be commended for a “stellar” performance. All of this new growth in FTES without new classrooms. Amazing!

Well done, Dr. Mark Zacovic! I know you cared about students and people. Thank you.

It is obvious that Kadow, Sparkman or Schlange did not consider FTES growth “performance” upon releasing Dr. Zacovic. So, what did they consider? And what criteria do they use for decision making? Apparently, its secret!

Elitism Rules MSJC Board

Monday, February 26th, 2007

Quote of the Day: Author Unknown
“Democracy should not be defined by an elite group of people who call themselves leaders and impose their wills on the citizenry through tactics of fear, intimidation, misinformation, propaganda and innuendo.”

Blog:? Unfortunately, Kadow, Sparkman and Schlange model such leadership.
